dictionary.title: eoActivity
dictionary.desc: terms relating to the activities of essential oils and their constituent compounds

entry.description: Non-steroidal chemical compounds with abortifacient activity.
agent that kills members of the arachnid subclass Acari
pharmaceutical drug used primarily for the treatment of hypertension (elevated blood pressure) and congestive heart failure
drugs that inhibit cholinesterases
drugs that inhibit cholinesterases
drugs that inhibit cholinesterases
A role played by the molecular entity or part thereof which causes the development of the pathological process of acne.
A substance or compounds that results in stabilization of physiological processes and promotion of homeostasis, an example being by decreased cellular sensitivity to stress.
Any pharmacological or immunological agent that modifies or enhances the effect of other agents such as drugs or vaccines while having few if any direct effects when given by itself.
Strictly, a substance intended to kill pests. In common usage, any substance used for controlling, preventing, or destroying animal, microbiological or plant pests.
a substance applied to skin, clothing, or other surfaces which discourages insects (mosquitos, specifically) from landing or climbing on that surface
a substance applied to skin, clothing, or other surfaces which discourages insects (mosquitos, specifically) from landing or climbing on that surface
Strictly, a substance intended to kill members of the class Insecta. In common usage, any substance used for preventing, destroying, repelling or controlling insects.
A chemical compound which causes the onset of an allergic reaction by interacting with any of the molecular pathways involved in an allergy.

An agent capable of relieving pain without the loss of consciousness or without producing anaesthesia. In addition, analgesic is a role played by a compound which is exhibited by a capability to cause a reduction of pain symptoms.
An agent that quells or blunts the libido.
Allergent causing anaphylaxis, an allergic reaction with symptoms such as itchy rash, throat swelling, low blood pressure.
An agent, usually a steroid hormone, that stimulates or controls the development and maintenance of male characteristics in vertebrates by binding to androgen receptors.
drug that causes anesthesia
An agent that induces or stimulates the physiologic angiogenesis process.
drug which reduces appetite
An agent which regulates the physiologic mechanisms that control the appetite and food intake.
drug which reduces appetite
substance intended to kill helminths parasitic worms
substance intended to kill helminths (parasitic worms)
A bioactive chemical compound or drug or used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.

Agents used to treat allergic reactions. Most of these drugs act by preventing the release of inflammatory mediators or inhibiting the actions of released mediators on their target cells. (from ama drug evaluations annual, 1994, p475)

Agents used to treat allergic reactions. Most of these drugs act by preventing the release of inflammatory mediators or inhibiting the actions of released mediators on their target cells. (from ama drug evaluations annual, 1994, p475)

Agents used to treat allergic reactions. Most of these drugs act by preventing the release of inflammatory mediators or inhibiting the actions of released mediators on their target cells. (from ama drug evaluations annual, 1994, p475)
A substance that counteracts hair loss.
Anti-allergent prohibiting the onset or state of anaphylaxis, an allergic reaction with symptoms such as itchy rash, throat swelling, low blood pressure.
A compound which inhibits or antagonises the biosynthesis or actions of androgens
A compound which inhibits or antagonises the biosynthesis or actions of androgens.
A compound which inhibits or antagonises the biosynthesis or actions of androgens
An agent that inhibits the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death.
Drugs that are used to treat asthma
A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria.
substance that kills bacteria
A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria.
A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria.

compound inhibiting the biosynthesis or actions of biofilms: groups of microorganisms in which cells stick together and often to a surface, become embedded within a slimy extracellular matrix that is composed of extracellular polymeric substances
anti-cancer agent
A substance that inhibits or prevents the proliferation of neoplasms.
chemical substances that prevent or reduce coagulation of blood, prolonging the clotting time
An agent, or antibody, that binds collagen and prevents buildup in connective tissues. It may be used to treat heart disease.

A compound or agent that combines with a Collagenase enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction. Collagenases are enzymes that break the peptide bonds in collagen
An agent that prevents blackheads blocking the pores of the skin.
class of medications
An agent, or essential oil, used to treat fungal infections of skin, hair, or nails.
Substances which lower blood glucose levels
Substances which lower blood glucose levels
An anti-diarrhoeal drug (or anti-diarrheal drug in American English) is any medication which provides symptomatic relief for diarrhoea
Miscellaneous agents found useful in the symptomatic treatment of diarrhea. They have no effect on the agent(s) that cause diarrhea, but merely alleviate the condition
A compound or agent that combines with elastase enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction.
drug used to prevent nausea or vomiting

A substance used to treat or prevent Erythema, redness of the skin or mucous membranes, caused by hyperemia (increased blood flow) in superficial capillaries. It occurs with any skin injury, infection, or inflammation
anti-feedants are organic compounds produced by plants to inhibit attack by insects and grazing animals
anti-fibrinolytics are a class of medication that are inhibitors of fibrinolysis

any pharmaceutical or chemical fungicide or fungistatic used to treat and prevent mycosis such as athlete's foot, ringworm, candidiasis, serious systemic infections such as cryptococcal meningitis, and others

any pharmaceutical or chemical fungicide or fungistatic used to treat and prevent mycosis such as athlete's foot, ringworm, candidiasis, serious systemic infections such as cryptococcal meningitis, and others

any pharmaceutical or chemical fungicide or fungistatic used to treat and prevent mycosis such as athlete's foot, ringworm, candidiasis, serious systemic infections such as cryptococcal meningitis, and others
An agent that relieves skin sores. A furuncle, is a deep folliculitis, infection of the hair follicle
substance that promotes hemostasis
drug that binds to but does not activate histamine receptors, thereby blocking the actions of histamine or histamine agonists
drug that binds to but does not activate histamine receptors, thereby blocking the actions of histamine or histamine agonists
drug that binds to but does not activate histamine receptors, thereby blocking the actions of histamine or histamine agonists
Hyperkeratinization American English or hyperkeratinisation in British) is a disorder of the cells lining the inside of a hair follicle

An agent that relieves severe flaking and cracking of the skin associated with hyperkeratosis, the thickening of the stratum corneum (the outermost layer of the epidermis), often associated with the presence of an abnormal quantity of keratin
all drugs for hypertension's treatment
An agent that prevents or relieves severly dry, scaly skin caused by ichthyosis.
Infection control
substance that reduces or suppresses inflammation
substance that acts locally on cutaneous or mucosal surfaces to produce inflammation
substance that acts locally on cutaneous or mucosal surfaces to produce inflammation
A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans

An agent, such as a herbal extrat, used for treatment of vitiligo white patches or dysfunctionalty of melanocyte cells that cause depigmentation resulting in loss of skin color with irregular white, milky white and pink patches.SAME
An agent or drug that stabilizes mood by controlling symptoms of mania, the abnormal psychological state of excitement.
An agent that prevents loss of skin pigmentation, characteristic of vitiligo.

An anti-leukotriene is a medication which functions to oppose the function of Leukotriene inflammatory mediators, thus countering bronchoconstriction, inflammation, microvascular permeability, and mucus secretion in asthma and COPD.

An anti-leukotriene is a medication which functions to oppose the function of Leukotriene inflammatory mediators, thus countering bronchoconstriction, inflammation, microvascular permeability, and mucus secretion in asthma and COPD.

Agents used in the treatment of malaria. They are usually classified on the basis of their action against plasmodia at different stages in their life cycle in the human. (from ama, drug evaluations annual, 1992, p1585)
A substance that inhibits or prevents the proliferation of Melanocytes, melanin-producing neural crest-derived cells located in the bottom layer (the stratum basale) of the skin's epidermis.
An agent used to relieve effects of melasma, characterized by a tan or dark skin discoloration often during pregnancy.
anti-microbial resistance to multiple drugs

An agent that interferes with the mutagenicity of a substance. The interference can be in the form of prevention of the transformation of a mutagenic compound into mutagen, inactivation, or otherwise the prevention of Mutagen-DNA reaction.

An agent that interferes with the mutagenicity of a substance. The interference can be in the form of prevention of the transformation of a mutagenic compound into mutagen, inactivation, or otherwise the prevention of Mutagen-DNA reaction.
medication that treats neuralgia
An agent that prevents the conversion of organic compounds into nitroso derivatives.
A class of drugs producing both physiological and psychological pain-relieving effects through a variety of mechanisms involving the central nervous system.
Agents that increase energy expenditure and weight loss by neural and chemical regulation
molecule that inhibits the oxidation of other molecules
An agent used to treat cellulite (Edematous Fibrosclerotic Panniculopathy), which is persistent subcutaneous fat that causes dimpling of the skin.
A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.
An agent that prevents the updtake of a substance by a cell, or tissue.
An agent, or anti-microbial, that controls sweat and body odor by preventing sweat reaching the skin surface, or by reducing the bacteria that causes body odour.
the inhibition of cell growth and multiplication. Cytostatic refers to a cellular component or medicine that inhibits cell growth
the inhibition of cell growth and multiplication. Cytostatic refers to a cellular component or medicine that inhibits cell growth
A chemical substance which inhibits the function of the endocrine glands, the biosynthesis of their secreted hormones, or the action of hormones upon their specific sites.
class of pharmaceuticals used in treatment of protozoan infection
drug, usually applied topically, that relieves pruritus (itching)

A substance that inhibits or prevents the psoriasis, a long-lasting autoimmune disease characterized by patches of abnormal skin. These skin patches are typically red, or purple on some people with darker skin, dry, itchy, and scaly.

A substance that inhibits or prevents the psoriasis, a long-lasting autoimmune disease characterized by patches of abnormal skin. These skin patches are typically red, or purple on some people with darker skin, dry, itchy, and scaly.

A substance that inhibits or prevents Purpura, a condition of red or purple discolored spots on the skin that do not blanch on applying pressure, caused by bleeding underneath the skin secondary to platelet, vascular, or coagulation disorders.
drug that prevents or reduces fever by lowering the body temperature from a raised state
drug that prevents or reduces fever by lowering the body temperature from a raised state
An agent that promotes healing through the formation of scar tissue. For example, sandalwood is a natural cicatrizant.
An agent that promotes healing through the formation of scar tissue. For example, sandalwood is a natural cicatrizant.
A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.
a pharmaceutical drug or other agent that suppresses muscle spasms
Agents that suppress cough. They act centrally on the medullary cough center. Expectorants, also used in the treatment of cough, act locally
class of drugs used to treat or ameliorate peptic ulcer or irritation of the gastrointestinal tract
class of drugs used to treat or ameliorate peptic ulcer or irritation of the gastrointestinal tract
A substance that destroys or inhibits replication of viruses.
An agent that prevents or diminishes the formation of wrinkles, often a factor of aging.
medication or other intervention that inhibits anxiety
Chemical agents or odorants that stimulate sexual desires
An agent that stimulates the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death.
An agent, or drug, that promotes the appetite or assists digestion
An agent, or drug, that promotes the appetite or assists digestion
Ascaricides are drugs to treat ascariasis that is caused by infections with parasitic nematodes (roundworms) of the genus Ascaris (giant intestinal roundworms).
chemical compound that tends to shrink or constrict body tissues
biological or chemical agent that stops bacteria from reproducing, while not necessarily killing them otherwise
drugs that act as central nervous system depressants
substance that dilates the bronchi and bronchioles, decreasing resistance in the respiratory airway and increasing airflow to the lungs
several medications that disrupt the movement of calcium (Ca2+) through calcium channels
several medications that disrupt the movement of calcium (Ca2+) through calcium channels
An agent which kills of organisms of the genus Candida , such as Candida albicans.
An agent inhibits growth of organisms of the genus Candida , such as Candida albicans.
substance, radionuclide, or radiation directly involved in causing cancer
substance, radionuclide, or radiation directly involved in causing cancer
An herb or preparation intended to either prevent formation of gas in the gastrointestinal tract or facilitate the expulsion of said gas, thereby combatting flatulence.
Agents that are used to stimulate evacuation of the bowels
substance that increase the volume of secretion of bile from the liver
drug or endogenous compound that lowers neurotransmission levels
A compound or agent that combines with the collagenase enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction.
An agent that stimulates production of collagen, the fibrous protein constituent of bone, cartilage, tendon, and other connective tissue.
substance used to impart colour to another substance or object
An agent that causes blackheads by blocking the pores of the skin.
An agent that resolves comedones or prevents the formation of new comedones (skin-coloured, small bumps (papules) frequently found on the forehead and chin of those with acne).
substance that acts in the brain stem or spinal cord to produce tonic or clonic convulsions, often by removing normal inhibitory tone
substances used to enhance the appearance or odor of the human body
A subclass of cyclooxygenase inhibitors with specificity for cyclooxygenase-1
A subclass of cyclooxygenase inhibitors with specificity for cyclooxygenase-2
An agent that destroys mosquitoes.
An agent that stimulates the activity of cytochrome-P450-1A, a cytochrome-P450 enzyme involved in phase I xenobiotic and drug metabolism, as well as metabolic activation of aromatic hydrocarbons.

An agent that stimulates the activity of cytochrome-P450-2B a cytochrome-P450 that catalyzes many reactions involved in drug metabolism (anti-cancer drugs cyclophosphamide and ifosphamide) and synthesis of cholesterol, steroids, lipids.
Functions to control the survival, growth, differentiation and effector function of tissues and cells
Functions to control the survival, growth, differentiation and effector function of tissues and cells
treatment of cancer with one or more cytotoxic anti-neoplastic drugs
drug to relieve nasal congestion
substance applied to the body to prevent body odor
A pigment-suppressing agent that has a lightening effect on skin.
route through which substances may be received
An agent that causes inflammation of the skin (dermatitis).
anti-microbial agent that is applied to non-living objects (compare: anti-sepsis) to reduce the number of microorganisms (unwanted germs and parasites) on them (compare:sterilization)
substance that promotes the production of urine
substance that induces labor and stimulates childbirth and delivery
substance that induces labor and stimulates childbirth and delivery
A compound or agent that combines with the elastase enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction.
drug that induces vomiting
herbs which stimulate blood flow in the pelvic area and uterus; some stimulate menstruation
Emollients are cosmetic preparations used for protecting, moisturizing, and lubricating the skin
An agent that reduces or inhibits the movement of muscles of the intestine.
An enterotoxin is a protein exotoxin released by a microorganism that targets the intestines
Drugs that clear mucus from airways
An agent that aids in the clearance of mucus from the airways, lungs, bronchi, and trachea.
Drugs that clear mucus from airways
pesticide used to kill fungi
GABAergic means pertaining to or affecting the neurotransmitter GABA
the ability of certain endogenous factors, chemical compounds and drugs to counteract gastric mucosal damage through mechanisms unrelated to inhibition of acid secretion
the property of chemical agents that damages the genetic information within a cell causing mutations, which may lead to cancer
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
Hemotoxins, haemotoxins or hematotoxins are toxins that destroy red blood cells (that is, cause haemotoxin), disrupt blood clotting, and/or cause organ degeneration and generalized tissue damage
An agent that causes hallucinations, perception anomalies, and other substantial subjective changes in thoughts, emotion, and consciousness.
chemical or drug-induced liver injury
chemical used to kill unwanted plants
Histamine antagonists are the drugs that bind to but do not activate histamine receptors, thereby blocking the actions of histamine or histamine agonists.
drug that binds to but does not activate histamine receptors, thereby blocking the actions of histamine or histamine agonists
A histamine agonist is a drug which causes increased activity at one or more of the four histamine receptor subtypes.
hygroscopic substance used to keep things moist. A humectant that is used as a food additive to prevent foodstuffs from drying out

A compound or agent that combines with the Hyaluronidase enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction. Hyaluronidases are a family of enzymes that catalyse the degradation of hyaluronic acid
class of psychoactive drugs whose primary function is to induce sleep and to be used in the treatment of insomnia (sleeplessness), or for surgical anesthesia

Hypolipidemic agents, cholesterol-lowering drugs or anti-hyperlipidemic agents, are a diverse group of pharmaceuticals that are used in the treatment of high levels of fats (lipids), such as cholesterol, in the blood (hyperlipidemia)
drug or chemical substance that induces body temperature cooling
Immunomodulators are the active agents of immunotherapy. They are a diverse array of recombinant, synthetic, and natural preparations.

A substance that augments, stimulates, activates, potentiates, or modulates the immune response at either the cellular or humoral level. A classical agent (Freund's adjuvant, BCG, Corynebacterium parvum, et al.) contains bacterial antigens. It could also be endogenous (e.g., histamine, interferon, transfer factor, tuftsin, interleukin-1). Its mode of action is either non-specific, resulting in increased immune responsiveness to a wide variety of antigens, or antigen-specific, i.e., affecting a restricted type of immune response to a narrow group of antigens. The therapeutic efficacy is related to its antigen-specific immunoadjuvanticity.

An agent that suppresses immune function by one of several mechanisms of action. Classical cytotoxic immunosuppressants act by inhibiting DNA synthesis. Others may act through activation of T-cells or by inhibiting the activation of helper cells. In addition, an immunosuppressive agent is a role played by a compound which is exhibited by a capability to diminish the extent and/or voracity of an immune response.
An agent that causes inflammation of a part of the body.
A chemical that attracts insects
A chemical that attracts insects
substance which repels insects
substance which repels insects
substance which repels insects
pesticide used against insects

Jubiavonials have the effect of insect hormones that physical maturation of some insects. Jubiavonials can be ingredients in insecticides which prevent insects from developing past the larval stage, thus preventing them from breeding.
drug that softens, separates, and causes desquamation of the cornified epithelium or horny layer of skin. An agent that removes warts and other lesions in which the epidermis produces excess skin.

an insecticide that is specifically targeted against the larval life stage of an insect. Their most common use is against mosquitoes. Larvicides may be contact poisons, stomach poisons, growth regulators, or (increasingly) biological control agents.
Agents that produce a soft formed stool, and relax and loosen the bowels, typically used over a protracted period, to relieve constipation
activity involved in the breakdown of lipids and involves hydrolysis of triglycerides into glycerol and three fatty acids

Compounds that bind to and inhibit that enzymatic activity of lipoxygenases. Included under this category are inhibitors that are specific for lipoxygenase subtypes and act to reduce the production of leukotrienes

An agent, such as a cromone medication, used to prevent or control certain allergic disorders. They block a calcium channel essential for mast cell degranulation, stabilizing the cell and thereby preventing the release of histamine and related mediators.
A compound or agent that promotes natural swelling and growth of breast tissues.
An agent that stimulates production of melanin, which determines skin and hair color and is naturally present in the skin to varying degrees.
A chemical substance that encourages a cell to commence cell division, triggering mitosis.
A substance, usually some form of a protein, that encourages a cell to commence cell division, triggering mitosis.
Pertaining to mitosis, a process of nuclear division in eukaryotic cells that occurs when a parent cell divides to produce two identical daughter cells.

Molluscicides are pesticides against molluscs, which are usually used in agriculture or gardening, in order to control gastropod pests specifically slugs and snails which damage crops or other valued plants by feeding on them.

A compound that alters the structure of mucus so as to decrease its viscosity and thereby facilitate its removal by ciliary action and expectoration. Compare with anti-tussives, which suppress the cough reflex, and expectorants, which are considered to increase the volume of secretions in the respiratory tract, so facilitating their removal by ciliary action and coughing.
drug or chemical that affects skeletal muscle function, decreases muscle tone
drug or chemical that affects skeletal muscle function, decreases muscle tone
A nematicide is a type of chemical pesticide used to kill plant-parasitic nematodes
Toxicity of the Kidneys
a medicine used to calm the nerves
relative preservation of neuronal structure and function
relative preservation of neuronal structure and function
An agent that quickens the functional activity of neurons.
substance poisonous or destructive to nerve tissue
substance poisonous or destructive to nerve tissue
The stopping, prevention or reduction of the activity of the enzyme ornithine decarboxylase
chemical compound used to oxidize another substance in a chemical reaction. A substance that removes electrons from another reactant in a redox reaction.

Drugs that stimulate contraction of the myometrium. They are used to induce labor, obstetric at term, to prevent or control postpartum or postabortion hemorrhage, and to assess fetal status in high risk pregnancies
An agent that retains ozone from a gas stream
drugs or chemicals which irradicate the infestation of human head lice
An agent that induces formation of fluid-filled blisters on the skin (pemphigoid), an auto-immune disorder.
A stimulant that is effective through the skin.
mixture used to produce a pleasant smell
drug or chemical which stimulates a radially symmetrical contraction and relaxation of muscles that propagates in a wave down a tube, in an anterograde direction
substance used to destroy pests
A semiochemical used in olfactory communication between organisms of the same species eliciting a change in sexual or social behaviour.
A semiochemical used in olfactory communication between organisms of the same species eliciting a change in sexual or social behaviour.
Having the ability to respond to light photoelectrically, or to respond to sunlight or ultraviolet radiation by chemical reaction.
A role played by a chemical compound which is known to induce a process of carcinogenesis by corrupting normal cellular pathways, leading to the acquistion of tumoral capabilities.
An agent, or allergen, which is activated by light to sensitize the allergic response, which causes a rash or other systemic effects upon exposure, including photodermatitis
Photoprotection is the biochemical process that helps organisms cope with molecular damage caused by sunlight
Photoprotection is the biochemical process that helps organisms cope with molecular damage caused by sunlight

A molecule that produces a chemical change in another molecule in a photochemicalprocess. Photosensitizers are commonly used in polymer chemistry in reactions such as photopolymerization, photocrosslinking, and photodegradation.Photosensitizers generally act by absorbing energy electromagentic radiation in the form of ultraviolet or visible light and transferring it to adjacent molecules.
An agent that renders the skin susceptible to damage (as sunburn or blisters) upon exposure to light and especially ultraviolet light.
An agent that renders the skin susceptible to damage (as sunburn or blisters) upon exposure to light and especially ultraviolet light.
An agent poisonous to plants, having a toxic effect on plant growth.
A biosynthetic precursor of collagen containing additional amino acid sequences at the amino-terminal and carboxyl-terminal ends of the polypeptide chains
a substance which stimulates the phase of growth called cell division, referred to as proliferation, where a cell, known as the mother cell, grows and divides to produce two daughter cells
Pro-oxidants are chemicals that induce oxidative stress, either by generating reactive oxygen species or by inhibiting anti-oxidant systems.
group of physiologically active lipid compounds
A compound that inhibits the action of prostaglandins.
A compound that inhibits the action of prostaglandins.
Pertaining to inflammation of the prostate gland.
A compound which inhibits or antagonizes the biosynthesis or actions of proteases (endopeptidases).
An EC 2.7.* (P-containing group transferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of protein kinases.
Pungency is the condition of having a strong, sharp smell or flavor that is often so strong that it is unpleasant

An agent that produces a soft formed stool, and relaxes and loosens the bowels, typically used over a protracted period, to relieve constipation. Compare with cathartic, which is a substance that accelerates defecation. A substances can be both a laxative and a cathartic.
Drugs used to protect against ionizing radiation. They are usually of interest for use in radiation therapy but have been considered for other, e.g. Military, purposes
Drugs used to protect against ionizing radiation. They are usually of interest for use in radiation therapy but have been considered for other, e.g. Military, purposes
An agent that causes irritation or inflammation of kydney tissue.
Reproductive toxicity is a hazard associated with some chemical substances, which interfere in some way with normal reproduction; such substances are called reprotoxic.
Reproductive toxicity is a hazard associated with some chemical substances, which interfere in some way with normal reproduction; such substances are called reprotoxic.
A substance for topical application that produces redness of the skin, by causing dilation of the capillaries and an increase in blood circulation.
An acaricide that kills mites of the genus Sarcoptes.

An agent, or drug, destructive to schistosomes, blood flukes transmitted by snails to human hosts in many parts of Africa, Brazil, and Asia. Praziquantel, albendazole, niridazole, metrifonate, oxamniquine hycanthone hydrochloride, and various salts of antimony, including stibophen, are potent anti-schistosomal agents.
An injectable irritant that is used in the treatment of varicose veins and that causes inflammation and subsequentfibrosis, thus obliterating the lumen of the vein.
A substance causing the halt in the production of sebum (sebostasis) by the sebaceous glands.
An agent that increases the production of serous mucus in the respiratory tract.
A central nervous system depressant used to induce drowsiness or sleep or to reduce psychological excitement or anxiety.
Chemical sensitizer, a chemical that causes allergic reaction in normal tissue after exposure
A food preservative that acts by chelating with metal cations (particularly those of copper, iron and nickel) that catalyse the oxidation of fats in food.
A drug or substance that increases the flow rate of saliva
A drug or chemical compound used in treating and healing of wounds.
A drug or chemical compound used in treating and healing of wounds
The series of events that restore integrity to a damaged tissue, following an injury
The series of events that restore integrity to a damaged tissue, following an injury
route of administration wherein active ingredients are delivered across the skin

A route of administration wherein active ingredients are delivered across the skin for systemic distribution. Examples include transdermal patches used for medicine delivery, and transdermal implants used for medical or aesthetic purposes.
An agent that causes spasms, which are sudden involuntary muscular contraction or convulsive movement
A contraceptive substance that destroys sperm, inserted vaginally prior to intercourse to prevent pregnancy.

An agent, or drug, that induces temporary improvements in either mental or physical functions or both. Examples of these kinds of effects may include enhanced alertness, wakefulness, and locomotion, among others.
topical skin product that helps protect against sunburn
topical skin product that helps protect against sunburn

A role played by a chemical compound in biological systems with adverse consequences in embryo developments, leading to birth defects, embryo death or altered development, growth retardation and functional defect.
An agent that kills termites, eusocial insects that are classified at the taxonomic rank of infraorder Isoptera, or as epifamily Termitoidae within the cockroach order Blattodea.
Strictly, a substance intended to kill pests. In common usage, any substance used for controlling, preventing, or destroying animal, microbiological or plant pests.
drug that induces tranquility in an individual

route of administration wherein active ingredients are delivered via diffusion through a mucous membrane. e.g. insufflation (snorting), sublingual, sublabial (between the lips and gingiva), or anal or vaginal suppositories.
An agent that kills Trichomonas organisms, such as in treating vaginitis that is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis
An agent that inhibits growth of protozoan parasites of the genus Trichomonas, such as Trichomonas vaginalis.
An agent that increases the activity of trypsin, a serine protease that hydrolyses proteins in the digestive system of many vertebrates.
A role played by a chemical compound which is known to induce a process of carcinogenesis by corrupting normal cellular pathways, leading to the acquistion of tumoral capabilities.
inhibitor that interferes with the action of tyrosinase, an enzyme that catalyses the oxidation of phenols (such as tyrosine) and is widespread in plants and animals
An agent that causes production of ulcers.
An agent that kills parasitic mites.
drug used to cause dilation of the blood vessels
An agent htat promotes vasorelaxation, or a reduction in vascular tension, as opposed to vasodilation which is an active widening of the blood vessels
An agent that acts against verruca, a contagious and usually painful wart on the sole of the foot.
Any compound that causes severe skin, eye and mucosal pain and irritation. Blister agent.
An agent that is destructive to bacteria of the genus Vibrio, especially V. cholerae.
A virucide is any physical or chemical agent that deactivates or destroys viruses. This differs from an anti-viral drug, which inhibits the proliferation of the virus.
A virucide is any physical or chemical agent that deactivates or destroys viruses. This differs from an anti-viral drug, which inhibits the proliferation of the virus.
Strictly, a substance intended to kill members of the class Insecta. In common usage, any substance used for preventing, destroying, repelling or controlling insects.
A drug used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.
A drug used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.
A drug used to treat attention deficit disorder, often a stimulant that promotes concentration and attention.
medication or other intervention that inhibits anxiety
Tooth decay, also known as dental caries or cavities, is a breakdown of teeth due to acids made by bacteria.
Any protective agent counteracting or neutralizing the action of poisons.
An agent that reduces the production or flaking of dandruff.
A drug used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.
A drug used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.
A drug used to treat or prevent skin disorders or for the routine care of skin.
An agent that prevents ecchymosis, or the rupture of blood vessels that leads to the passage of blood into subcutaneous tissue.
A substance that when introduced into the body stimulates the production of an antibody. Antigens include toxins, bacteria, foreign blood cells, and the cells of transplanted organs.
An agent or drug that modulates the transmission of glutamate, or inhibits glutamate currents, for muscle relaxation, anti-seizure, or neuroprotective effects. May be used for ALS.
An agent or drug, which may be a stimulant, used to treat ADHD.
An agent acting against keratosis, overgrowth of horny tissue of the skin (such as warts).
An agent used to treat mange, a skin disease of mammals caused by parasitic mites and occasionally communicable to humans.
A substance that inhibits or prevents the proliferation of neoplasms.
A substance that destroys or inhibits replication of viruses.
An agent that relieves symptoms of skin diseases that cause formation of fine, branny scales.
A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.
An agent that relieves inflammation or irritation of the nerve root of a tooth.
A substance that destroys or inhibits replication of viruses.
An agent that removes or diminishes warts.
An agent that relieves or diminishes abnormal dryness of the skin, eyes, or mucous membranes (xerosis), or that may diminish the normal hardening of aging tissue.
An insecticide used against aphids.
Strictly, a substance intended to kill pests. In common usage, any substance used for controlling, preventing, or destroying animal, microbiological or plant pests.
Bee repellant
An agent that acts to dilate arteries to increase blood flow in the heart, or away form the heart.
A substance able to kill or inhibit the activity of beetles

A counterirritant is a substance which creates irritation or mild inflammation in one location with the goal of lessening discomfort and/or inflammation in another location. This strategy falls into the more general category of counterstimulation
substances that cause the intestines to contract
substance that triggers epilepsy
An agent that stimulates the activity of lipase, and enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of fats (lipids).
A compound or agent that combines with an enzyme in such a manner as to prevent the normal substrate-enzyme combination and the catalytic reaction.
